channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Three Women of Bucha: Their Deaths and Lives
item.description: New reporting illuminates the fortitude of three women — a former public servant, an animal lover, a grandmother — who were victims of Russian brutality.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

item.title: Despite Its Barrage of Missiles, Russia Still Loses Ground in Ukraine
item.description: “They use their expensive rockets for nothing, just to frighten people,” a member of Ukraine’s Parliament said of Russian attacks on the country’s cities and infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops riding in the back of a truck near the village of Sydorov in eastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Belarus Wavers as Putin Presses It to Join Ukraine War
item.description: The country’s strongman, Aleksandr Lukashenko, finds himself in a bind. He survives with support from Russia, but entering the fight could be “political suicide.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops moving through a recently recaptured village in eastern Ukraine. Russia hopes that the threat of troops from Belarus will force Ukraine to divert its troops from front lines in the east and south.

item.title: Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker Debate in Georgia
item.description: Herschel Walker, needing to recover from weeks of negative headlines, went on the offensive against Senator Raphael Warnock in what is likely to be the only debate of their crucial Senate race.
item.dc:creator: Maya King and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times; Nicole Buchanan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herschel Walker and Senator Raphael Warnock

item.title: Five Key Moments From the Walker-Warnock Debate in Georgia
item.description: Herschel Walker had a badge, Raphael Warnock had a quip about his opponent’s law enforcement claims, and the candidates sparred on abortion.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Maya King
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The debate in Georgia with Senator Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker was highly anticipated and spawned watch parties, including this one hosted by the Black Men’s Initiative in Atlanta.

item.title: How a Republican Could Win the Oregon Governor’s Race
item.description: In a wild governor’s race, an independent candidate is siphoning Democratic votes and a billionaire Nike co-founder is pouring in money — giving an anti-abortion Republican a path to victory.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Leah Nash for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christine Drazan is hoping to become the first Republican in 40 years to win a governor’s race in Oregon.

item.title: The Rent Revolution Is Coming
item.description: For the 44 million households who rent a home or apartment in the U.S., inflation keeps pushing costs higher and higher. Anger is rising too. It could be a breaking point.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty
item.media:credit: Barrett Emke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tiana Caldwell, a co-founder and Board President of KC Tenants, outside the East Patrol Division Station in Kansas City after being arrested during the group's disruption of a city council vote on a new set of housing ordinances.

item.title: Beijing Turns Into a Fortress Ahead of the Communist Party Congress
item.description: The authorities in China have arrested a million criminal suspects, curbed travel to Beijing to keep Covid out, and deployed an army of neighborhood monitors.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Great Hall of the People (Beijing, China)
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of Xi Jinping on display at the military museum with the slogan: “Inspiring the Three Armed Forces to Forge Ahead.”

item.title: How Security Forces Cracked Down in Southeastern Iran
item.description: A New York Times analysis of witness testimony and videos reveals a bloody scene that unfolded last month in Zahedan during Friday Prayer, with mats as stretchers and bodies piled in cars.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Nilo Tabrizy and Ishaan Jhaveri
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How One School Avoided the Pandemic Plunge in Math Scores
item.description: Benjamin Franklin Elementary in Connecticut overhauled the way it taught — and the way it ran the classroom. Every minute counted.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nationally, test scores have fallen in math even more than in reading. At Benjamin Franklin Elementary, children have defied the trend.

item.title: Peter Thiel, Major U.S. Political Donor, Is Said to Pursue Maltese Citizenship
item.description: Obtaining citizenship in Malta would provide another passport for Mr. Thiel, who is one of the largest individual donors for the U.S. midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Justin Scheck
item.media:credit: Brendan Smialowski/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Peter Thiel, the billionaire technology investor, during the Republican National Convention in 2016. Mr. Thiel was born in Germany and holds U.S. and New Zealand passports.

item.title: The Student Loan Borrowers Who Keep Missing Out on Relief
item.description: In a startling change, many in the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) program may no longer be eligible for up to $20,000 in debt cancellation.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Robert Neubecker

item.title: Student Debt Cancellation Site Opens for Beta Testing
item.description: The Education Department said it was “beta testing” a form that it intends to use to eliminate millions of federal student loans.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Jemal Countess/Getty Images For We, The 45 Million
item.media:description: A woman urged President Biden to cancel student debt.

item.title: Strength Training Beginners Guide: How to Make the Workout a Habit
item.description: For real this time.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Friedman
item.media:credit: Ryan Frigillana for The New York Times

item.title: Donald Trump Has Told Americans Exactly Who He Is
item.description: Even without his testimony, the Jan. 6 committee has revealed what we need to know about the former president.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Wegman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: The Jan. 6 Hearings Are Over. These 3 Things Must Happen Now.
item.description: The torch now passes to other actors who hold the power to achieve accountability for the attack on the Capitol.
item.dc:creator: Norman Eisen, Danielle Brian and E. Danya Perry
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by Jon Cherry and Free Agents Limited via Getty Images

item.title: Same-Sex Marriage Is a Religious Freedom
item.description: If the law allows same-sex couples to be treated differently from other couples, then our religious freedom to be married is not complete.
item.dc:creator: Steven Paulikas
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times

item.title: New York Can Do More to Help the Latest Wave of Migrants
item.description: This crisis should prompt Mayor Eric Adams and Gov. Kathy Hochul to move forward with policies to build more housing in New York City and its suburbs.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yefferson Rojas is one of more than 19,400 asylum seekers who have arrived in New York since April.

item.title: This Is How to Put the Supreme Court in Its Place
item.description: Democrats in the 21st Century should not make the same mistake Republicans in the 19th Century did.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: Wonking Out: What’s Really Happening to Inflation?
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; image by NoDerog via Getty Images

item.title: In the Face of Inflation, Let’s Give Everyone a Lift
item.description: Cost-of-living increases shouldn’t be limited to Social Security.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: What a Report of Extreme Racism Teaches Us
item.description: Claims of especially stark and unfiltered racist abuse often do not turn out to have been true.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter
item.media:credit: Delcan and Co.

item.title: Dressing Up
item.description: As the seasons change and more people return to in-person work, figuring out what to wear can be a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: When Biden’s Folksiness Veers Into Folklore and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

item.title: George Saunders on ‘Lincoln in the Bardo’
item.description: The writer, celebrated for his short stories, discusses his 2017 debut novel, and the journalist Patrick Radden Keefe talks about “Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland.”

item.title: Food waste solutions
item.description: Around the world, lawmakers and entrepreneurs are taking steps to tackle two of humanity’s most pressing problems: hunger and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: A smart composing bin for residential drop-off in Queens, New York City.

item.title: Juror Describes a Bid to Deliver Death Sentence in Parkland Trial
item.description: A juror says he and others tried to persuade those who wanted to spare the gunman’s life by making them look again at the evidence of his rampage, including the weapon he used to kill 17 people.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Amy Beth Bennett
item.media:description: Judge Elizabeth A. Scherer in court this week for the sentencing trial of the gunman responsible for the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School mass shooting.

item.title: LA City Council Scandal Highlights Latin American Racism in the U.S.
item.description: Disparaging remarks about Oaxacans from the Los Angeles City Council president shocked a city that prides itself on tolerance. But they highlighted a history of racism within the Latino community.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Adam Perez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ivan Vasquez at his restaurant Madre in West Hollywood on Friday.

item.title: Nearly ‘Erased by History’: African Americans Search for Lost Graves
item.description: Families and volunteers seek out and restore abandoned cemeteries as a way of recovering their own personal stories.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Al J. Thompson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donna Brodus Forrest, far right, praying at the likely grave of her grandmother, Viola Brodus,at the Old Groveland Cemetery in Groveland, Fla.

item.title: What the $24.6 Billion Kroger-Albertsons Merger Could Mean for Groceries
item.description: Two of the largest U.S. supermarket chains hope to join forces as inflation pushes food prices higher and as Amazon and Walmart become more powerful.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers inside a Kroger store in a suburb of Cincinnati, where the company is headquartered.

item.title: The Nap Bishop Is Spreading the Good Word: Rest
item.description: Tricia Hersey, founder of the Nap Ministry, sees rest as a revolutionary way to push back on America’s obsession with productivity at all costs.
item.dc:creator: Melonyce McAfee
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tricia Hersey, a.k.a. the Nap Bishop, has been experimenting with the idea of rest as liberation for nearly a decade.

item.title: Can Supplements Really Help With Depression or Anxiety?
item.description: Here’s what the evidence says about what works (and what doesn’t).
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Ecotherapists Are Working to Make the Outdoors More Inclusive
item.description: Amid pandemic stress and racial violence, many communities of color have turned to wilderness areas for healing.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Logan Lynette for The New York Times

item.title: Can Cold Water Plunges Really Reduce Anxiety and Depression?
item.description: Early research suggests this age-old practice might benefit mental health, but more research is needed.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Williams
item.media:credit: Tyler Comrie

item.title: Why Daydreaming Is Actually Good For Your Brain
item.description: Letting your mind wander can benefit the brain, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasus

item.title: Robert De Niro’s Career in Five Artifacts
item.description: The actor recently donated hundreds of boxes of scripts, props, notes and other objects from his work on “Raging Bull,” “Taxi Driver” and more. We dived in.
item.dc:creator: Dina Gachman
item.media:credit: Columbia/TriStar
item.media:description: Robert De Niro in a scene from “Taxi Driver.” The license he obtained to work as a cabby is part of his donated archives.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
